title: Parametric Lego Technic Rotor Blade Liftarm

description.text:
Parametric Lego Technic Rotor Blade Liftarm.

Following parameters can be changed:

NrOfBladeHoles = 1;
NrOfBlades = 3;
Thickness = 3.9;
EasyPrintable = 0;

If the parameter "EasyPrintable" is set to 1, then the part will be still functional compatible, but much easier to print.

To get a nice fit with the Lego pins and axles, it is recommended to drill the holes with a drill of diameter 4.9 mm.

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLZ9YYlwfPK3hPlnTYDHNpiB0cvopAabgT

THERE IS A NEW BOLT
It uses a springloaded extractor, and should give the most consistent extraction of the shells and improved ejection.

These are the parts I used for my xzeus shotgun build, using sledgefire shells.
Some of these parts will probably need tweaking, and I'll upload as I test things that work or don't.
The shell stop files needed tweaks, and I also tweaked the lifter with a bit of foam to keep shells from going too far backwards. You may also want to remove some front material from the lifter, about a half inch off the front.
This is not a drop in mod, and requires extensive shellwork and building to work.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I ran mine with default setting for pla on the Monoprice Maker Select Plus. I'd recommend a dense or solid infill.

Breech Test is the file name for the properly sized breech, it's not actually a test.
Bolt Mk10 is deeper, so you can use thicker foam for the seal against the shell. The extractor is slightly larger, and may need to be shaved down, or maybe it will work perfect for you.

Some sanding required

These parts need tweaked after they've been printed to both fit and have an airtight seal.
The bolt specifically will need the middle drilled out and smoothed to allow air to flow through the bolt/shell interface.

Bolt Prep

The bolt will need the middle drilled out and smoothed to allow air to flow through the bolt/shell interface.
After the hole is drilled, you'll need to use 2mm craft foam to make a gasket to allow a seal with the shells.
These were designed in Sketchup, and there were some oddities from using that program, such as the bolt not printing with the hold in the middle

The lifter interacts with a slanted angle at the back of the boltsled, but needs to have a lot of trigger material removed so it can lift up. The shellstop cams are just glued to the sides of the bolt sled, facing opposite directions. You'll need to make sure that the cam for the shellstop (the larger part) only interacts at the very and of the prime, so that the lifter moves after that on the forward motion. The shellstops require you to cut them forward of the base body of the blaster, on both sides.

author: Bishbish2000

description.text:
Project requirements:

1x Parabolic shroud
1x Jabra classic headset
1x Smartphone, Bluetooth recorder or the like
1x Sense of adventure

Optional:

Foam to place in front of microphone

See update below

Here we have a printable parabolic microphone case type device for a Jabra Bluetooth headset that I picked up a while ago.

You will need to destroy the case for this project. Photos are included and details listed of how to obtain the correct shape we're looking for.

The mic will swivel in place for correct focal adjustment. It's all just about mathematically correct, within about a few hundredths of a mm in the file. It works quite well at its purpose as a directional amp. The theory was there so I made this. Should have some audio samples up soon.

UPDATE: While this project was an... idea, the practice was something I couldn't quite bodge with what little time I had. An uninterrupted time later, I've realized that you can't route the audio from the mic to the headset with their implementation of some dinky little QFP and Bluetooth protocols. So... it's got to be some software to interact with the Bluetooth directly and either reroute the signals from mic to phone back to headset, which is convoluted to say the least, or you have to record the audio you're hoping to catch directly and forgo live feedback. 11/22/17

At this point, I don't have a method for live audio, I'm sorry. If anyone has any ideas to eliminate the lag that would be present doing it the dumb way, let me know.

If you don't need quality audio recordings from a distance, or any feedback whatsoever, this device is for you!

Printer:

Dildahmetron

Resolution:

0.2 mm layers

Infill:

10%

Notes:

0.4 mm nozzle, 0.2 mm layer heights, supports for the flat overhangs holding mic in place, support for the bottom the the cup is optional. Pictures shown are without that optional support.
It's recommended.

Work might not be done

It really depends on how serious about sound you are. I can imagine that taking 200 grit sand paper to the inside surface, then painting it with a high fill auto primer would be worth while. If you're really into it, you happen to be creepy as all hell, or your just like painting, you could camouflage the inside to have a more stealthy feel.

Post a make, I'd love to see these used in some fashion. It was just kind of an idea I had a few days ago.

I was inspired by the interior structure of bone to designed this six sided die. I tried to ensure that each side was volumetrically similar so it would roll properly.
I have one coming from Shapeways in stainless steel. I will post pics when it arrives.
I used Makerware9.9.9 and used fine settings with 100% infill and 2 shells. Raft and support are needed,

author: Ujur35

print_settings.Notes:: Print with low speed as parts are small and delicate.

description.text:
Description

This is a no-sanding bearing anti-wobbling for a Tevo Tarantula printer, also wrongly called oldham coupler
NOTE: This is a project still in development. Feel free to contribute, remix and edit.

Dimensions

X axis mount: 2x M4 screws (same as stock)
Bearing screws: 4x M3 screws + 4x washers
Bearings: Common 608ZZ (I bought mine in Decathlon)

Functional description

This was designed by me because I did not manage to properly sand the common oldhams you find for this printer, so I decided to design one based on 3 simple rules:
1) Use bearings instead of plastic-on-plastic
2) Use the polished side of plastic that faces the glass bed, instead of sanding it
3) No need to sand anything

Printing tips

Print with low speed as parts are small and delicate. You may need a drill to enlarge the holes a bit if needed

Installation and usage tips

1) Find the best combination for fitting all together in order to have the lowest twist angle.
2) In my case I decided to remove 1 of the 4 wheels from the X axis from the Z rod side so the oldham could move freely.
3) Because there is always a twist angle error (in my case of about 0.1mm), while printing, make some circles around your print and use them to calibrate the first layer height.
4) While calibrating if you have this angle error, always calibrate from lower Z to higher Z, because that is how your print normally comes out.
5) I haven't tried this with lift Z while retracting setting.

Others

Designed by: Vasco Baptista
Designed in: AutoCAD
Attached files: STL and DWG

Printer:

TEVO Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Print with low speed as parts are small and delicate.

This simple Raspberry Pi camera module mount is used in conjunction with a cheap pose-able magic arm clamp. I also use the Pi Camera HDMI Cable Extension modules. These eliminate the need for long flat form cables and allow the use of standard HDMI cables to connect the camera.

The HDMI modules are available here:
https://www.tindie.com/products/freto/pi-camera-hdmi-cable-extension/

The Magic arm I found on eBay for about £12.

I'm using some M2 x 15mm hex spacers, anything above 8mm long should work to stand the HDMI cable far enough away from the mount.

You can mount direct without the standoffs if using the flat form cable.

title: Aquarium Shrimp (and other small water creatures) catcher

description.text:
Catch those fast little fellows without hassle.
The shrimp get sucked into the tube and put into the basket where you can collect them with the basket and put them into a new tank or whatever.
Print the basket and the net holding ring in vase mode. The air lift without supports
The green tube is from the aquarium store.
The air lift has two versions, one with a tube to put the air hose around and one without where you can glue in a tube. The second option proved to be better for me as the tube as not that stable with my printer.
Best results are with the intake about a finger or two wide above the ground at a feeding spot.

title: Mini-Z MR-01 Chassi H-plate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Chassi H-plate for MR-01.
My friend broke his and it´s hard to find so I designed a new for him.
Just came up with this design and I haven´t had the time to test it yet(wednesday).
Today is a new day and it didn´t fit at all. I got the wrong measurements but now I probably hav solved it!(all holes were slightly wrong/to small and the spacing between them)
I also added the triangel that is placed underneth the H-bar. That part you want to have a support or something under when printing due to the holes underneath it.

There is 3 different types/ stiffnesses on the plates. That idea I found on shapeways from a guy called Fovea3d, but his was for MR-02 and not free, but this is ;)
I will also put them up here one by one so you don´t need to print them all if you don´t need them.
Any questions or you want to change anything, just let me know!
Enjoy!

description.text:
This is the "TOUCH EXTERIOR SURFACING.STEP" model taken from the "Oculus touch-accessory-guidelines-1.0.1"

I just converted them to .STL files and mirrored it to make two.
This is an accurate model in size and curves that can be used to model attachments for the Oculus Touch.

This is a phone stand I created to work with any phone with or without a case. You are able to rest the phone upright or on its side and you can use the peg to determine the angle of the phone. I printed it with supports and you need to use supports or it will not work because there are through cuts all the way through it to reduce the amount of plastic needed. Also it doesn't have to be just a phone stand it can really be used for whatever you need to prop up. Thanks for your time and keep an eye out for what I have coming soon.
I just threw together a basic stylus for a resistive touchscreen.

author: smartdesign

title: 2018 Happy New Year Fun Glasses
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
These are an evolution from my 2016 New Year's Glasses which were featured in several online 3D printing magazines and websites. It uses the same arms with rugged hinges and the glasses are also easy on the nose’s skin as well as on the ears. I also included two versions of the arms the standard length (most common) and longer ones.

If you want to paint the numbers in different colors then print the glasses in a white material to have a good color base.

I printed the arms with black PLA at 220 degrees and 45 degrees bed.
The Glasses themselves I printed them with white PETG at 345 degrees and 100 degrees bed.
Fill is 10% and no need for supports because they are already in the uploaded STL file. Don't forget to cut them off before inserting the arms.
You will also need to use some CA or gorilla glue to secure the arms in place.

Enjoy this New Year’s Eve wearing this fun Glasses.

auggie.

MakerBot

This is a 0.0073 scale model of the German heavy rail artillery piece. I added details of the breach and recoil mechanism. This was scaled down quite a bit to be printable. If issues arise in printing, get back to me and I'll see if there are adjustments I can make, at this size, many details like handrails may be below printer resolution, I eliminated most of the handrails, these so a modeler can add wire as railing, now the gun base stl is good

author: andrew_cholagh

description.text:
I have an Anet A8 and I always like to keep a small bottle of oil to lube the parts next to or on top of the printer but it keeps falling off or rather i keep knocking it off.
So i designed this to screw down on top of the printer. I use an old 10ml Vape Fluid bottle which has a 20mm Base to keep my oil i use for the printer, this fits into the holder i made perfectly and i use one of the frame mount screws to hold it in place, instead of having to drill into the frame.
I made it in 123D Designs as its a simple CAD to use and this was not a complicated item.

Hope this is of use to some of you feel free to edit it to your needs.

title: CR10 120mm Fan mod for Control Box

description.text:
If you don't fancy replacing all 3 of the Control Box fans you can just use a single 120mm exhaust, it has more than enough air flow and will cost a lot less. You'll want to wire the fan to one of the 12v connectors on the motherboard, rather than the PSU (which will only turn the fan on when hot). I've also removed the cover from the PSU for better airflow.

If you don't remove the PSU cover, then please leave the stock PSU fan on. - There's simply not enough ventilation in the PSU casing

The caveat here is you'll need some legs, I'm using Shift31's that can be found here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2413227

Print is 2.2mm thick which is plenty strong enough with PLA. Included option to print in 2 halves, the screws from the fan will keep the peices together but make sure you use a washer for the middle screw (pictured)

EDIT -
This is where you need to power the fan:
https://i.imgur.com/LJRhcaF.png

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

comments.text:
Great ! I'm going to print this to reduce noise and probably increase components lifetime because off the better airflow.
One question: I shoud remove the psu fan and cover but keep the other two fans (motherboard and back one) ? My plan is to change this two ones for noctua fo keep it quiet.
comments.author: Atzingen

comments.text: The motherboard fans are very noisey, and they're on all the time.
comments.author: Atzingen

comments.text: Could you provide a link for the fan you purchased for use with this? Also, please clarify as to where it is to be plugged in, seems to be a lot of confusion on that. Thank you!
comments.author: slvrbllt44

comments.text: Did you ever figure out where it needs to be plugged in?
comments.author: slvrbllt44

comments.text: Yes, piece of cake! I plugged it in to the two pin plug on the PSU where the old fan was plugged in. Weird though because the new fan is a 3 pin. It will work as long as you pull gently up on the base of the two pin connector on the PSU and remove it completely. That way you can push the 3 pin receptacle on to the exposed two pins. I said weird earlier because the fan still varies its speed without the 3rd pin being connected. I also disconnected the two other fans inside the unit (motherboard & rear exhaust fan) and left the cover off of the PSU for better circulation. it works like a champ and it is much, much quieter! My new fan has a LED light ring around it that looks pretty cool as well. I HIGHLY recommend this mod! Great job on the mounting plate, mine fit like a glove!
comments.author: notmyrealaccount

comments.text: The fan varies it's speed because it's actually turning on and off. The motherboard supplies constant 12v power to fans, but the PSU has a thermometer on it and only powers the fan on when it's hot. The issue you get with how you've done it is the motherboard components only have cooling when the PSU wants to be cooled.
comments.author: slvrbllt44

comments.text: I have the fan directly connected to the two pin connector on the PSU and the fan  runs constantly, but it does vary its speed. I've been running it this way for almost a month now and have had zero cooling issues. I regularly physically check the air exhausting from the side vents (I have the fan blowing inwards) and it has never even felt warm and there's a heck of a lot of air  coming out :)

author: adylinn

description.text: update: I had a flaw in my original design where it ran into the frame. I updated the design to hook over the top edge now. Works like a champ. I also wired my fan to an old wall wart power supply 9v (yes, underpowered but its what I had) and the motor is cool to the touch the whole time. I have a Printrbot Simple (v2) and I've been printing non-stop with this little thing. Sometimes when I print too long the extruder motor starts to heat up the filament feeding area, which can cause the filament to kink and jam. People seem to solve this with a fan to cool the motor down. I couldn't figure out how to power the fan off the board, so I just wired an old 12v computer case fan to a 9V battery so it blows on my motor to cool it. Yes, I'm under powering it. But it works, and cools the motor fairly well. Should be good for long prints. Right now it just rests on the top Z arm with a little hook action around it, and the motor itself, and seems pretty secure. If it falls off, I can always screw it down or add a bit of double side stick tape. This is the part of the 3d Printing I love the most. See problem, Come up with Idea, Print Idea, Test Idea, Success! (or fail, and iterate till Success!) Printed in PLA black, .3 mm Height on the aforementioned Printrbot Simple. This thing was made with Tinkercad. https://tinkercad.com/things/kPXUFc6BPM3

author: KySyth

description.text:
BOXMODULE2 is a collaborative art piece. These simple blocks interlock and create a large 2.77-meter wide sphere. Print the block from the .gcode provided on your favorite 3d printer(or have someone 3d print it for you), sign the side, and send to the following address. The artist Kevin Dunn will be assembling the blocks during the month of October 2017. The final piece will be displayed in the following months and the piece will be available for all to continue on with constructing their own spheres.

C/O Wilma Daniels Gallery
Cape Fear Community College
411 N Front St.
Wilmington, NC 28401

Warning the stl files are not scaled to the correct size. Use the g-code provided to participate. The object will print at the correct size from the g-code. It is in marlin/reprap and is designed for a mono-price mini-select. It is setup for 1.75 diameter PLA. If you are slicing your own g-code make sure that the object is 60 mm on the wide side of the cube(picture provided). That way it will fit the other blocks in the sculpture.

title: Mark VII Medical Tricorder - Star Trek TNG

description.text:
This is a remix of the excellent Medical Tricorder from @vesperk38 with two changes:
-The scanner holder and base were combined into a single object
-The hinges were replaced with those from another excellent Tricorder by @arhuerl

Also included are a modified set of graphics adapted to this specific layout.

Printing:
-Scanner was printed with wide end down, with brim, without support.
-Flip was printed with hinges down, with supports.
-Base was printed with scanner holder end down, with brim, without support.
-Use a metal wire through the hinges to link the two sections.

Graphics:
-Printed on a color laser printer and attached with Scotch double-sided tape.

Note: I experimented with painting the buttons but the printed labels were always cleaner looking. It is also difficult to cut out holes for the buttons in the glossy paper I was using. I ended up (for now) just taping the graphics over the printed buttons on the base object and it looked much better.

To do:
-Find small plastic jewels for better buttons
-Paint other buttons and sensors

Prusa

For the nostalgic, you can use your existing Lite Brite pegs, or pick some up on your favorite on-line site. This stand holds 102 pegs, enough for some fairly simple designs, yet small enough not to take up too much desk space. Can use small LED "tea lights" or similar illumination source.

The base is designed with a small incline to keep the stand from tipping forward, and is deep and wide enough to hold 2 tea lights.

10-7-2017 - added LED-based tea light holder and base for use as a light source. Can also use small flashlight or other light source that would fit in the tea light holder (40 mm x 60 mm).

The design...

The Lite Brite pegs are slightly tapered, and measured approximately 4.25 mm at their bases when fully inserted, but this made for a very snug fit. After a little experimentation, I found that 4.75 mm gave enough play yet didn't let in too much light around the pegs.

The feet of the pegs are also approximately 15 mm deep, so the "screen" is 10 mm deep to keep the pegs straight, with a 5 mm border (larger at the bottom to fit into the base) to help visually offset the screen.

STL file included, so feel free to modify as you see fit.

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
Recently, Brook from Printrbot launched a campaign to put 3d printers in classrooms called #adoptabot.You can find out more about #adoptabot here: https://www.adoptabot.org/ .

The wire management is essential in my mind to making these bots safer for classrooms. I went ahead and modeled a cover for the printrboard that allows access to the microSD, USB, and power plug. It simply clips in on the left of the board and secures with a single screw. Much better than the rats nest I had originally. Plenty of ventilation available and room for wire wraps to enter on the left side.

Required: You will also need to print 4 of the simple standoff spaces included so the board doesn't sit directly against the body of the printer. This is actually a great thing to do regardless of using the cover for airflow and reducing strain on parts of the board. Original screws and such are not a problem to reuse. No other parts needed.

Let me know how this works for your #adoptabot build. I've included the Fusion 3D archive file and STEP file so you are able to customize if needed.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

10

Notes:

The only supports needed is from the screw hole down to the plate. I didn't print it with supports under the two tabs or in the microSD slot. You're printer bridging ability might differ and support might be needed in those areas.
This will be used to make a sand mold. The mold will be used to cast the heart in brass. This is to replace a key chain that my mother had for as long as I can remember and recently lost.

title: Bebop 2 Prop Balancer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
To remove jello effect on videos, you have to balance your props.

This is a magnetic propeller balancer for Parrot Bebop 2 Quadcopter and other.

Based on a common prop balancer as often sold on ebay,
I decided to create bigger side plates for free prop rotation.

Remember, Bebop 2 props have a 152mm diameter.
Total hight of balancer is now 12cm, instead of original 5cm hight.

The screw-holes are 3mm.
The magnet-holes are 5mm.

Distance tubes from original are recycled, also magnets and screws.
Enjoy your better videos and please post pictures of your balancer.

21.10.2017:
Added distance tubes 56mm long.
Fit perfekt for the bigger prop balancer axis sold by aero-naut.de

description.text:
I have a small table next to my printing desk. It was crowded before this mount and for better browsing experience screen might be verticle. Well I tried this and liked once upon years ago I used to turn my CRT monitor on side. That was not thin, I were happy with using that like that. At the end of 10 hour print I hanged my monitor on printing desks wall. Now I have some more place to put other things on the table.

PS for Downloaders :

I was not expecting anyone to download this, but 5 downloads in 4 days occured. I should say for hanging monitor is not advised, only in your own control and responsibility of any usage. For my monitor it has a leg at 7,9 inch diameter. And its height has a difference between foreside and backside, but those hang mounts are regularly same size, while hanging I used PAPER to raise a little high for the backside mounts. So this must be explained and I did.

description.text: I got an original Prusa Printer with multi material upgrade, When i built my enclosure I made a shelf under the printer for the filament. spools of plastic can get heavy especially four of them at once, I also figured that extra weight underneath the printer might help knock out the vibration noise that this printer makes. to be able to fit all four spools on the shelf the holder needed to be flat, first i tried sandwiching BBs(making a giant ball bearing but that was way to loud, so i designed this spool holder, which was inspired by a top toy.

I've always had an issue with keeping the Y axis cable chain from interfering with the carriage when homing from time to time and when I switched to a bigger cable chain the issue got worse. I saw something like this for other printers but not the FT-5 so I sketched this up and when I printed it in S3D I expanded the Z to 200mm. It clips on the melamine and the cable train sets perfectly inside it and out of the way of the carriage. It's nothing fancy but it does the job.

title: TEVO Black Widow Y-Carriage MGN12 Conversion

description.text:
https://youtu.be/yf8EObWTr1k
You will need two MGN12 Rails. I used 450mm ones and they cover the whole bed movement area. You should be able to use other lengths...Just make sure your bed does not come off the rails.

MGN12 x 2
M3 Bolts and T-nuts as needed to install. (Will update with exact quantities when done).

  1. Attach the MGN12 rails to the printed plate
  2. Attach the bolt bracket to the printed plate the same way as you did with stock. YOU WILL NEED SPACERS (I will include a printable one soon)
  3. Using below alignment tools place the two rails and plate on your 4080 C-beam and bolt the whole thing down
  4. Make sure your belt is tight and parallel to the 4080
  5. Attach the Stock Y carriage to the plate using the now empty wheel holes

I used https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2368837 to align the rails. Thanks to @theinternal

author: dbfrompw

description.text:
I have had head crashes or other mishaps that have stressed the head platform and broken some of the orange acrylic plastic struts on my Deltaprintr Kickstarter printer. In the past, I have been able to purchase replacements/spares from Deltaprintr, but they no longer have a supply.
Being down to no spares, and with one just glued back together, I decided to try designing and printing my own. I tried single-piece, but distortion at the edges of the print area were too severe to make usable parts. I also noticed that some of the print-area-edge-distortion seemed to be related to the strut end pinching against the u-joints.
Also, the critical dimension of the strut arm is exactly 255mm between the 3mm screw hole centers, to within 0.1 mm or so. So I needed to be precise and consistent.
In the end, I succeeded by designing a 2-piece strut (2 identical pieces per strut), with a jig to hold them while gluing to enforce the critical dimension. I used ABS for strength and because of the easy availability of ABS pipe glue.
So, you first need to build a jig with two 3mm screws (I used nails) centers exaclty 255 mm apart.
Then for each strut, print 2 parts. I used ABS settings with a brim. There are tabs at the ends of the pieces to tape down during printing to avoid warping (I do not have a heated bed). The tabs snip off easily.
Trim the brim and tabs off each part, and then drill out the end hole to a smooth 3mm. Place each part on one of the jig pins, flat side up, apply glue (carefully) amd press together. Make sure they are nicely set on the pins. (ABS pipe glue is black, if you don't like that color you could make your own glue slurry with scrap ABS and acetone....)
When you mount the assembled arms, make sure the flat side of the strut is on the side of the strut arm AWAY from the u-joint. This will stop the arm pinching distortion when the head platform is near the print area edges.

RESULTS: After replacing all the arms (24 parts!) I have to say that the printer performs better than before! Far less distortion at the edges, and generally a little better behaved. I think these arms are actually stiffer than the original arms.
Even if you don't want to do the while thing, it would be wise to print up a couple for spares, since Deltaprintr no longer supplies these strut arms.

title: Let's Split Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a case for the Let's Split keyboard. I originally had an acrylic sandwich case(116mm x 86mm) and wanted to reuse it for this case. So if you have an acrylic case and want something enclosed, you wont need to desolder switches to use this. The bottom acrylic plate is also usable if you'd like a see through bottom. I've included a solid bottom door and a switch plate so if you don't have the acrylic case, you can still use this. I made the USB openings tall to allow for various configurations. There is a 6° slope to the case.

Everything securely snaps together and requires no screws or standoffs. There are recesses for 8mm bumpons on the bottom plate; you'll want to get some. I have oriented all parts exactly as they should be printed. No supports needed if your printer can handle some short bridging.

author: 3dxl

description.text:
Photogrammetric model of a jackrabbit skull from my personal collection. There is some damage to the lower jaw. In a few places I had to manually close some holes that developed in the thinnest portions of the model. On the actual specimen the bone is close to "see-through" (~0.2 mm thick) in these areas. I reduced the number of polygons from the original versions of the models by approximately a factor of 10 to balance between detail and file size. I can post higher poly files if there is interest.

To print this skull, I’d cut each element into several pieces, in orientations designed to minimize the amount of necessary support. I’m presenting them as they are so that you will have the greatest amount of freedom using them in ways that fit your needs.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lysozyme

The catalytic residues (Glu35 and Asp52) and disulfide bonds are represented as spheres.

Me3D

Yes

Yes

The model was created using Protein Data Bank entry 1DPX:
http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore.do?structureId=1DPX

The model was created with VMD:
http://www.ks.uiuc.edu/Research/vmd/

Hen Egg-White Lysozyme is an enzyme used widely in biochemical education. Its activity can be easily assayed by spectrophotometry, it can be unfolded (by reducing agents) and refoled in the presence of cysteine and cystine. It can be easily crystallized. A semester-long biochemistry lab is described here: http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/ed079p366

Please see the linked publication:
http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/ed079p366

The linked publication is "A Novel and Innovative Biochemistry Laboratory: Crystal Growth of Hen Egg White Lysozyme" by Elizabeth Garrett, Audrey Wehr, Rebecca Hedge, David L. Roberts and Jacqueline R. Roberts of the Department of Chemistry, DePauw University, Greencastle, IN 46135. Journal of Chemical Education (2002) Vol. 79, p 366. http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/ed079p366

author: N0de

description.text: This is a variant of my hex tie that does not require thread to string the hexes together.  Instead, the hexes are connected via 3d printed snap-on clips.  Like the original, the goal is to make a tie that drapes like cloth, yet is 3d printed.

The clips and hexes work well in both ABS or PLA and are optimized for .2 or .4mm layer height.  The clips should always be printed sideways (as per the STL) to maximize flexibility.  You can use a few in a different color to make the tie more interesting (see photo).  
Figure out how many hexes you will need by measuring your desired tie length and deciding on the pattern (e.g. middle column of 18, 2 side columns of 10, and 2 edge columns of 3 full hexes, plus half hexes on top of each side & edge column as in the photo).  Each hex is 24mm tall and the links are oriented so the top/bottom of the hex will be a flat side rather than a point.   If you use my tie design, a 44cm tie will use about 44 hexes, 6 half hexes, 10 third hexes (optionally), and more than 100 clips, just for the tie.  The neck band will probably be ~18 links and 34 clips.  Of course, you can make your own pattern using the full, half, and third hex pieces.   
[UPDATE: the last picture I uploaded shows a thinner variant that uses 16 half hexes and 28 full hexes, not including the clasp. If you don't want that fat 70's tie look, you might prefer this design instead of the one described above.]  
Once you have printed the hex pieces, lay them out and snap the clips on.  It works best if you slide the clip onto the flat part of the hex from the side, and then push them sideways over the cylindrical part, rather than trying to pop them straight over the cylinder.  They should snap into place and turn freely.  
The top link of the tie should have the hex column acetoned/glued to the middle of it, facing out, and oriented the same way as the hex (flat side down, points to the side).   
To put on the tie, push one side of the neck band (ie, the clasp) over the hex column.  It should angle up and to the side.  Place the band around your neck, and push the other side of the neck band over the hex column.  The tie cover snaps on last.

title: Huts for Conan Boardgames and other dungeon crawlers

description.text:
These are models for Huts and palisade obstacles in Monolith's Conan boardgames. There are several versions of each.

The hexagonal huts are separated into one side sections which have versions for a wall, a broken wall, a door, and a wall that can be positioned at a concave angle.

The round stone hut pieces are one sort each since they cannot be wrecked like others. There is a round roof that sits atop the three wall sections which holds them together nicely. The notch on the roof orients with the door to make finding the peg placement easier.

The wooden pen pieces form one of the square buildings on the map and come in door, wrecked, and wall versions.

Lastly there is the palisade which can be printed and be set up on the interior sections of the map with palisade sections to help with the LOS determination.

The "Hut Door" piece is the cloth depicted on the map board and sits on pegs on the door pieces.

Almost all of these pieces come in three flavors. Material A, Material B, and Combined. If you have a dual material printer you can print Material A and B superimposed on each other to create a nice effect. Depending on your printer you may need to tweak the models slightly. If you have a single material printer then you can ignore the A and B models and stick with the Combined versions.

Everything is already sized to fit the map fairly accurately. They can be printed without rafts or supports. In fact i'm using the bridging and unsupported sections of the models to contribute to the "shabby hut chic" that's depicted on the map.

Printer Brand:

CEL

Printer:

CEL Robox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium or better

Infill:

Very little required

Notes:

You may be tempted to add supports but these will print very well in PLA with no supports. Give it a shot. It may take some tweaking with your printer, but the main goal here is to create dilapidated looking huts with straw and daub barely holding them together. This is one of the cases where a slightly bad print is preferable!

Thank you user @teuf94 for the fantastic photos of the painted model!

description.text: This is version 5 of the dog bag holder i've designed. It includes a screw on lid in order to prevent the lid from loosening over time. The rear treat holder design has remained the same.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Low setting in Cura

Infill:

50

Four different versions for your 3D printing pleasure. UPDATE: found one I left out; see downloads for new file. It was the one on the right in the photo.
I used Chroma Strand Labs Inova-2008 3mm (PETg) transparent. Great stuff, no stink, food safe, no warp, but needs Elmer's glue stick on PEI. Fan or no fan seems not to make any difference. After a few layers I increased the material feed to 115% but I am not sure that was necessary. Just wanted to make sure there was adequate material extruded.
These are solid models that were setup in vase, single outline corkscrew mode. 3 bottom layers, zero top layers. 235C/80C nozzle/bed temperatures. The models are completely solid and must be set up in your slicer to produce a vase, unless for some strange reason you want to waste material on a solid lump.
If 3 or 4 people ask I will modify the files so they can be printed with thicker walls instead of just single wall.

Note: AngleSpy made the comment that the print came out too light in regards to weight.
That's generally the nature of single wall vase mode. Fast and light.
You can make the print heavier by turning off the Vase/Corkscrew mode and adding bottom layers. Make sure top layers are zero. You can also use one or two perimeter layers. I have not used Slic3r or Cura in years, so I can't recall how they work. I use S3D; pretty easy to do when editing the process on the Layers tab. Probably similar in other progs.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.35mm

Infill:

n/a
I used MicroCADAM Helix Modeling (RIP, last updated, June, 2001; and some translating from Freecad) to generate the designs.

description.text:
First release in the OpenForge cobblestone streets set. These are in a fan pattern.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

For each street tile, print yourself one of street.cobble.fan.* and a base of the same size (2x2, 2x4 or 4x4). The streets are in 25mm square basis (which matches Dwarven Forge). If you want that size, print without changes, and print one of the 25mm bases. If you instead want inch squares, scale the street tile on X and Y by 101.6% and print one of the inch bases. Finally, if you want wyloch stile tiles (1.25" per square) scale the X and Y by 127%.

Note: This thing used to have bases, but now all bases for OpenForge City Streets are kept in their own thingiverse entry: OpenForge 2.0 City Street Bases

Printing

I've recently entered into a deal where I am reviewing 3d printers. The prints for this object are the first I've done on the printer I'm reviewing. Gearbest provided me with their Tronxy X5s printer. I've only just finished getting the printer working, so there are still some problems (like stringing) that require tuning for me to fix, but overall, I'm very happy with the output on these first prints, especially given the printer's pretty low pricepoint. I'm going to continue making prints for many of the releases over the next few months with this printer so we can see how it improves.

Other Street Tiles

You can find the rest of this set as it gets released, along with some other city street tiles that people from around thingiverse have been creating in the OpenForge 2 Streets Collection

Changelog
  • 10/24/2017 - removed all the bases. Now all bases for OpenForge City Streets are store in their own entry

title: Tablet Stand with push button adjustments

description.text:
This is a tablet/phone stand that can be adjusted by pushing the button on the side. All parts are completely 3d printable parts including the spring and locking mechanism. It will even print on many smaller printers. (150mm) I have printed it on my Mono Price Select Mini and my CR-10S and they both came out great.

The only part that needs any support while printing is the front leg and it will need full support for the hinge area. The rest of the parts print fine for me with no support. I would print the front and back on their thin sides, (see the combined plate for the recommended position)

I hope you enjoy it.

I included a combined plate but I normally print the parts separately because the front leg is the only one that needs support and removing supports from the spring would be a pain. It is a good size for a tablet (even my 10 inch tablet) but if you want it for a phone you can scale it down to 75% which is about a perfect size for a phone. I included a picture that shows the difference between full sizes and 75% and even one 50%. (I was still designing when I printed those smaller ones, so please ignore how the buttons on them are way too long)

How to assemble: I included a picture that shows the direction each part goes in the legs hinge. Place both legs together, then push in the Gear, next push in the Spring, next push in the Spring Cap and the last step is the small pin to hold them in place. You will need to turn the spring cap so the hole lines up with the hole in the front leg hinge so the cap pin can go in.

The diamond pattern cutouts were only to reduce the amount of plastic and print time while still avoiding supports. Feel free to make them solid or create your own design. I only ask that you do not sell them without my permission first.

description.text:
As I started playing table-top RPG games with kids (I got some print-it-yourself PDFs from Drive Through RPG), I found that the paper stand-up minifigures need some sort of a stand. Small folded pieces of printer paper are just too light to stand still - every wind blast, no matter how light, blows them away.

I'm sure there are a lot of stand things out there, but most of them are for cardboard figures, 1mm thick and more, and most of them are have rectangle stands.

My design features:

  • narrow slot - suitable for thin printer paper
  • slot is close-sided
    • paper figure does not slip away sideways
    • improved resistance against being squeezed too much by a kid
  • no sharp edges and angles

The stand fits 25mm wide figures, slot depth is 10mm, everything is customizable.

comments.text: I play this game with my kids, and it is awesome to see what you came up with! I had something that looks like an inverted T that you fold the character over and pin in place with some clips. I lose the clips, though, so this is a great idea. Nice work!

description.text:

title: Pokeball Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I had a request to make a Pokeball spinner and this is the result. It's not perfect and the center pegs are weak and it will break if you drop it. I've just re-glued the center when that has happened. I used a standard 22mm skateboard bearing for the center of the spinner. I also designed it so it can be held by small hands. In the beginning I made it a round sphere, but that made it hard to hold, so I modified the "fillet" to allow for a flat top and bottom to make it easier to hold. Also you can spin it two ways. One by holding the top and bottom and one by holding the center and spinning the ball creating a strobe effect.

description.text:
A VRM cooling shroud designed to fit over a 120mm exhaust fan in the back of a PC.

This is designed to help provide cooling for the very hot voltage regulator modules found on poorly designed motherboards, most noticeably on some recent Ryzen mobos. The idea is that the rear exhaust fan sucks air through the shroud, creating turbulance around the VRMs and keeping them cool.

The part is designed to be printed flat on it's back, without the need for support (hence the vents). There's still a bit of overhang (~13mm bridges), so a part cooling fan is recommended if using PLA.
Need a 3D printer, file and glue. (Workshop glue)

title: Modular Layer Fan for E3D Titan/V6 (Quick Release Magnetic Mounting)

description.text:
Demo video of it in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gte1hK7m6W8

This is a clean modular layer fan I designed that mounts directly to the E3D Titan/V6 hot end direct drive combo and requires no tools to remove for maintenance etc. The layer fan mounts cleanly and securely to the face of the Titan extruder using four strong 6mm x 3mm neodymium magnets that clamp to the existing bolt heads on the titan. It uses a 40mm x 40mm x 10mm (I used a GDSTIME brand fan but others may fit if they are the same size) blower and has options for a basic single duct nozzle or dual side nozzles. Depending on your printer tolerances the magnets can either just be pressed in or may need to be glued in place.

Required Parts:
1x - 40mm x 10mm blower fan - http://amzn.to/2xV3ABZ (12v) or http://amzn.to/2gbVZYg (24v)
4x - 6mm x 3mm round magnets - http://amzn.to/2xihPUD (pack of 30)

Optional Parts (fan should press fit but these will give added security if it wiggles):
2x - M3 x 10mm socket head screw - http://amzn.to/2xhDcVW (cheapest to get an assortment of lengths if you don't already have some)
2x - M3 x 3mm threaded inserts - http://amzn.to/2gdcDH1

Please share your makes!

Get OpenBuilds compatible v-wheels and bearings in red or blue! https://3dvice.co

title: Customizable Led/Neopixel Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hey Guys,
this a very small, modern Led Lamp I designed in Fusion360.
The special thing is that there's a thread modelled in to it so can change your 'Tops' to what ever you want!

One file is called 'ThreadPreset.step'. You can download it an modify it to fit your design.

It's designed to fit in

  • a 16xNeopixel ring from Adafruit (https://www.adafruit.com/product/1463)
  • an Arduino Nano (https://store.arduino.cc/arduino-nano)

Its powered by the Mini-USB-input from the arduino nano.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I printed the foot with black PLA
I printed the tops with transparent Pla

but you can also use translucent filaments for the tops.

Assembly
  1. Remove supports (if you used them)
  2. Solder 3 wires to the 5V Output (5V), the Ground Pin (GND) and the digital pin 6 (D6)
  3. Solder the wires to the Neopixel
    for steps 2. ande 3.: see the tutorial of adafruid (https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-neopixel-
    uberguide/basic-connections)
  4. Fit the Arduino Nano into the housing and the wire through the according slot in the foot.
  5. Fit in the Neopixel Ring into the slot above the Arduino. If you want you can glue these
    parts.
  6. To programm the Arduino look here:
    -Installation of library: https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-neopixel-uberguide/arduino-library-installation
    -Coding :https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-neopixel-uberguide/arduino/library

I loved b1sh0p Tabletop idea but wanted to add some fluff to the starting and ending tiles.

What better than beginning a journey in a nice city ?
What better to allure young adventurer that the prospect of a treasure ?

The City tile is a merge of the End tile with Catan city wall.

The Treasure tile is a merge of the End tile with the Small Hinged Chest.

Sadly, with the downscaling of the chest (aggravated by the fact that I printed the whole game at 80%), the hinges are far from perfect. But the lid will still fit the chest, so I will contend myself with it.

The chest is large enough to fit small coins (10c €) or small candies :p

print_settings.Notes:: CR-10

description.text:
We had a poorly mounted switch on MCK-Y, the Lego Mouse Droid so I needed to build a new mount for that.

The rocker switch in question is a $2 switch from banggood.

It needs to hang about 4" under the frame of the mouse droid, so I made long arms for it. Turns out they're almost too long, if I reprint it I need about 1/2" shorter. I can barely get my finger between it and the floor and he turned himself off going over a wire cover!

I also threw in a cutout here of just the mounting area in case that was helpful for people to remix or mashup with their own projects (like put it in the side of a case or something).

I measured carefully, so I figured it would "work", but I was amazed that it seemed to fit perfectly, very impressed.

Full disclosure: Gearbest gave me the CR-10 that I printed this with, so I feel sort of obligated to put it through it's paces.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm (Standard)

Infill:

12%

Notes:

I used Simplify 3D to print. Supports probably aren't strictly necessary, but I wanted the area where the clasp goes in to be pretty clean so I manually placed a support on those two bits.

I printed the long one on its side, with the curvier side down. If you were printing the flat plate, you wouldn't need supports since the hole wouldn't be vertical.

I used 12% infill because 10% just wasn't doing much in the way of criss-crosses when I looked at the preview and I thought it'd be too little.

I usually print in ABS, so that was a bit of a concern with the CR-10. I chose 80C for the platform temperature and 230C for the extruder temp. A different part seemed to seperate a little, so maybe I should've done a higher temp, but those vary depending on filaments, the whim of the gods and all that so I'm sure folks will need to adjust temps for their own preferences.

The CR-10 has a heated bed, but it doesn't have an enclosure. I'm pretty sure that big things would warp in ABS, and was a bit worried about this since it's so long. I think I got lucky because it's a big long "U" shape so it had room to flex?

That said, the bottom feet with the screw holes were printed in vertical layers and weren't exactly straight. I wouldn't have noticed, but I was trying to reuse a screw from another area on the droid and the wobble ate up some of the margin for error in my screw length. We almost couldn't get the nut on. (I could've just used a longer screw!)

Full disclosure: Gearbest gave me the CR-10 that I printed this with, so I've been using it a bit. So far I'm pretty happy with it.

title: 50mm Pulley Variant Surface Mount (2x 608 bearing)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a basic pulley surface mount variant. It has a 50mm main wheel and will handle up to a 10mm or 3/8" line. You need two 608 skate bearings, and two 8mm x 35-40mm bolts and nuts. This version will surface mount with 4 sheetrock or better screws. There are two wheel designs one fancy and one easier to print. I find that the wheels print well in the standing position with support. If you have problems printing that way the simpler design can be printed on its side. I may include a no bearing wheel very soon. The sides should be printed flat with 30% or more infill. I used 2mm walls, top and bottom with 30% infill. That basically makes the sides 100% with a little infill around the top block. There will be more variants, so stay tuned.
Enjoy.

You can get the bearings here:
608ZZ http://amzn.to/2i5t08X

If you like my designs why not tip me a dollar or two. Your support will allow me to spend more time on these designs and their variations. Thanks!

title: Nimble Mount on OpenBuilds anti backlash nutblock

description.text:
EDIT: It seems the adapter is a little too flexible in 1 area allowing Nimble and V6 to flex when pushed hard. We decided to redo the adapter and have a new design. But before we put it up, we want to make sure it is as stiff as it needs to be.

Small bracket to mount a Nimble (and a V6) onto the OpenBuilds anti backlash nut block. This block is modified to fit onto a MGN-12C slider (added 4 holes).
One of our customers, a true innovator, requested this and it was kind of tricky to get it right without losing too much print volume or "printability" Now the mount can even be printed in two orientations.

Simply bolt the mount and nut block to the slider, insert the V6, slide the standard Groove mount adapter over the top of the V6 and mount the Nimble. Really simple mount.
Added an optional clamp for the V6. If you want added security, or if you want to use the mount without the Nimble, you can use the clamp to fix the V6 into the mount.

The STL models are checked and optimised. The parts that need a different orientation to print properly are rotated to the preferred printing position.

The Nimble Extruder

With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lightest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and can be mounted in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available from Zesty Technology.

author: ZestyTech

title: CR-10 Dual Z axis with single stepper. Low cost high precision.

description.text:
The CR10 has a single Z axis leadscrew and I have no issue with this it really produces superb prints. From an engineering point of view a better idea would be to have a leadscrew at both ends. There is an upgrade kit available which uses a second stepper motor but I understand these can get out of sync when power is switched off and on and the bed must be re leveled every time.
My solution links the screws with a toothed belt and is driven by the existing single stepper. It cannot get out of sync.
All the parts cost less that £12.00 ( US $16.00) including delivery!
There is a bit of metalwork involved but you only need a saw. file and drill. If you really cannot do metalwork I have designed a printed bracket with the same dimensions. Be warned though this has not been tried out but it should be OK.
Parts needed include
600mm leadscrew and nut https://goo.gl/fM8znL
GT2 Aluminum timing belt pulley 36 teeth : https://goo.gl/hv9dVU ( 2 required) Make sure you order the 36 tooth pulley.
GT2 852mm Timing Belt: https://goo.gl/iXa4sv ( be sure to get the correct length)
Flexible Shaft Coupling: https://goo.gl/qfUhEe
Bearings: https://goo.gl/HnzTqr
Video https://youtu.be/-ASBhJiU8NI
Instructions http://myfordboy.blogspot.co.uk/p/the-cr10-has-single-z-axis-leadscrew.html
Beware of ordering the leadscrew form other than the link given. There are 2 forms of 8mm leadscrew available.
One is a 4 start thread that gives a 8mm travel for one turn, the other is single start that would move the nut 2mm per turn.
The details are not given very clearly on some sites. I made the mistake and ordered the wrong one to start with.
UPDATE
Some people have said the printed bracket fits and others say the fixing holes are too close together. I have uploaded another file which has a slot so should fit OK.

Printer:

CR 10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

No support was needed for the printed bracket. Note the models need rotating before printing.
LH bearing retainer STL dimension corrected.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/-ASBhJiU8NI" ></iframe>

You do not understand the design. The flexible coupling is only used to hold the leadscrew between the bearings. A coupler could be used instead. There is no issue with one screw in compression and one in tension as the right hand leadscrew is directly coupled to the pulley.
The belt has a 180 deg contact on the pulleys for best power transmission.. The belt does not ever need tensioning once initially set up.

Just a heads up on this project. Beware of ordering the leadscrew form other than the link given. There are 2 forms of 8mm leadscrew available.
One is a 4 start thread that gives a 2mm travel for one turn, the other is single start that would move the nut 8mm per turn.
The details are not given very clearly on some sites. I made the mistake and ordered the wrong one to start with.
comments.author: Caster

comments.text: I got the wrong one too, changing the number of steps/mm in firmware or using M92 Z800 (in my case I got the 4mm / rotation T8 rod, hence the 800) will fix the issues. Hope this helps anyone who gets the wrong T8 rod. Only thing is you need to replace the existing one too. I was lucky because I ordered 2 T8's/.
comments.author: Caster

comments.text: Which lead screw is required then? The 4 start or single start?
comments.author: Caster

comments.text: You need the 4 start. i recommend ordering it from the link i gave to ensure you get the correct one. Some descriptions for similar items do not mention if it is 4 start or single start.

comments.author: Bastii92

comments.text: Caster, you're missing out on $.  You have a potential goldmine.  Why?  I ordered and installed the dual axis kit from Tiny Machines.  It's a great kit, but.....even with the second Z axis motor/lead screw, the two motors act independently, which continues to keep one side of my horizontal bar uneven.  I have to, before each print, re-measure to keep them both level before leveling the bed.  Your design continually keeps the Z axis totally even, no continued adjusting.  You should have ordered a number of sets of all parts needed and sold them to CR-10 users at a reasonable price.  Even at $35 to $45 a set, you'd be making a decent profit.

title: Compact AIO Fan with retractable Z-Probe for E3D V6/clone Hotend

description.text:
[26-Feb-18] Added Main Body source file for customization.
[22-Nov-17] Added a smaller 4020 Fan mount to reduce overall footprint.
[16-Oct-17] Trimmed the rivet pin to 20mm measuring from cap to tip. Updated pics. Re-designed Servo mount Set V.2 uploaded. Y offset reduced. Screw mounted micro-switch.
[10-Oct-17] Firmware info added
[7-Oct-17] An updated version of probe mount is uploaded, this will allow printing without support. Sorry for the mistake.
I do realize that some rivets may have bigger caps, and cannot fit in the probe mount. There is a simple solution to this is by mounting the mandrel to an electric drill. While running the drill, use a file to trim the cap to correct size. I use this method to polish the tip.

================================
This is a remix from a compact fan mount designed for the E3D V6 or clones. I want a mount that can fit in tight space, light weight, with a z-probe and "Cheap". I saw many designs with different types of probe, conductive, capacitive or mechanical, but none fit my goal or is too expensive (BLtouch or alike). So I decided to build one with parts that I owned or can be salvaged from my used stuff. Here is the BOM list,

  • All printed parts
  • 30mm axial fan and 50mm radial Blower fan( u should have these already)
  • 1 X 9/10g Micro servo (the cheapest will do) like this one https://hobbyking.com/en_us/hobbykingtm-hk15178-analog-servo-1-4kg-0-09sec-10g.html
  • Servo extension cable like this https://hobbyking.com/en_us/60cm-servo-lead-extention-jr-with-hook-26awg-5pcs-bag.html or make your own.
  • 1 X 12V to 5V DC-DC buck convertor (u may not need this if your servo does not cause reset when being activated)
  • 1 X micro switch like the one shown in the photo (I salvaged it from a dead mouse's middle wheel button)
  • cables and plugs for connecting probe to the RAMPS board(I use AWG24 wire with black connectors(Dupont) which are commonly used in PC)
  • Screws:
    1 M3x35 with nuts for extruder mount
    1 M3x25 with nuts for blower fan
    1 M3x20 Self tapping for blower fan
    1 M2x10 Self tapping as push rod(also see below)
    9 M2.6x8 Self tapping for joining parts to the extruder mount(or glue them if u don't have these small screws, I salvaged them from several toy quads)
  • 3mm in length Plastic tubing as push rod spacer(I use a section of PTFE(Bowden) tube and trimmed it to fit the slot on the probe mount)
  • 1 X aluminum POP rivet @ 1/8", other specs will work, but u need to adj the part to fit (u might need to trim the length, the one I have is trimmed to 23MM from the tip of the pin to the bottom of the cap and the tip is rounded off using a file)

During the course of design, I used these CAD models and I am here to thank them for their great works.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:999655
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1077412
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:341689
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1897864
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/sunon-30mm-fan-kde1203pfb1-8

Printer:

UM2 Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 /0.35 nozzle

Infill:

75%-100%

Notes:

At least the extruder mount should be printed in high temp filament like ABS/PETG. Other parts can be printed in PLA when used without a printer enclosure.

Notes on Assembling:
  1. Assemble the extruder mount first
  2. Fit fan mount and servo mount to the extruder with screws or glue.
  3. Fit the pin to the probe mount, make sure it moves freely inside.
  4. Solder cables to the micro switch.
  5. Insert the micro switch into the mount with the button facing down until it is touching the cap of the pin but not triggering the switch, then fix it by tape/glue.
  6. Assemble the rest except the servo horn(we need to set it up in firmware before mounting)
  7. For wiring and firmware setting, I would recommend visiting http://lokspace.eu/adding-9g-servo-based-autolevel-sensor-to-your-3d-printer/
    This is a good place to start with and I wish u all good luck and happy printing.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/dNwq1UoGYvc" ></iframe>
Here is the probe in action......

I will provide some info about the firmware configuration,
If you have previous experience in setting up a z-probe, you may skip this section.
Otherwise, let's move on. I'm using Marlin 1.1.5. You can download the latest and recompile the same way.
There are 3 major alterations in the configuration.h (in the Marlin folder).

  1. Enabling Servo Support
    a.Z-probe options -->> Probe type, uncomment
    #define Z_ENDSTOP_SERVO_NR 0 // Defaults to SERVO 0 connector.
    #define Z_SERVO_ANGLES {70,145} //Deploy and Stow angles. find these values using M280 command in Prontaface
    b.Z-probe offset, modify
    #define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 25 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
    #define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -10 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
    #define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Z offset: -below +above [use M851 to set z offset instead)
    You may change the homing speed to suit your needs accordingly or use default.
    c.Enable the "M48" repeatability test, uncomment
    #define Z_MIN_PROBE_REPEATABILITY_TEST <-- accuracy test in Prontaface
    d.This informs Marlin 1 servo is installed, leave the other servo settings to default.
    #define NUM_SERVOS 1 // Servo index starts with 0 for M280 command

  2. Z-Probe connection settings
    Since, I am designing this as an add-on and deploy whenever needed, I still have the Z-min endstop in place for homing. Therefore, I use the Z-max connector for my z-probe)
    #define Z_MIN_PROBE_USES_Z_MIN_ENDSTOP_PIN <-------- comment this out
    #define Z_MIN_PROBE_ENDSTOP <-------- enable this (assume using Z-max endstop by default)
    #define USE_ZMAX_PLUG <-------- tell marlin you have a switch connected here.

  3. Bed leveling type -->> I prefer Bilinear(for a typical bed size, but you can try the others).
    #define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_BILINEAR <-------- remember to set the boundaries for probing

Finally, re-compile and upload it to the printer for calibration.

Assuming you have completed assembling(except the servo horn) the parts, then power off, connect the probe and servo to the RAMPS connectors and then boot up your printer. If everything goes as planned, you should notice that the servo will rotate to the preset stow position. Launch Prontaface and connect using USB.

By using the servo move command (M280), find out the range of your servo movement, eg. "M280 P0 S?"(?=0-255). Mine has a range from 30-150. Locate the "Deploy" and "Stow" position value(your can trial fit the servo horn to see if the movement is correct or not) then disconnect the printer. With this values, modify/update the Marlin configuration.h accordingly and upload it to the printer again. (Fine tune the "Deploy" position so that the underside of the slot on the probe should be touching/pressing the servo mount with no plays or movement. This is crucial to the accuracy of the probe)

Complete the probe assembly with the servo horn and push rod. It should stow the probe when the printer boots. Connect with Prontaface again and send a G29 to your printer to see if it will "Home-Deploy-Probe-Stow" correctly.

In order to find the correct Z-offset, you can use Z-offset "M851", Deploy "M401", Stow "M402", trigger status "M119" command to find the value. Then issue M500 to save it to printer's EEPROM. See here http://marlinfw.org/docs/gcode/M851.html. Sometimes, you may need to fine tune it, just modify the value through your printer's console before doing G29 and then save it to the EEPROM if you are satisfied with the value, or include it in the Start code of your slicer.

That's all for now, happy probing!

author: UEPONYA

description.text:
A kit of parts to join tubes to make an A-frame.
Mine is made from fibreglass tent poles which are a bit under 13mm in diameter. These just happened to be on special at $4au for a set of four (plus other bits).
Otherwise I would have used 16mm curtain rod (which is tube actually).
It should be possible to re-scale the parts for other sizes.
My printrbot sits in a bamboo serving tray which has inside dimensions of 300*475mm.
The poles are 700mm long so the angle at the apex comes out close to 24 deg. The parts are over engineered and are overkill to support a few kilos of plastic. I have left some early versions of parts in the SU file.

I printed the parts in PLA.
In my case the long tubes are 700mm.
The two cross pieces are 440mm.
So is the removable top bar.
The four 45deg braces were 295mm.
The short cross pieces on the "A" are 100mm. I was planning on gluing it together but it seems be be working happily unglued.

title: New Y clamp for hypercube evo (tension release)

description.text:
Just like how my A8's X-belt tensioner works, the mod releases the clamping force (caused by tightening the belt) from the Y bearings to the 2 x-rods.

In CoreXY design, as your belts get tighter, your Y-carriage(2 of them) have the tendency to become closer to each other, but they cant, they are held by the Y-bearings. Thus, you end up with bending your bearings towards the rods.

i made M3 and M4 nut version.

and a plug for carbon fiber rods (that is what i'm using, as the CB rods are hollow)

choose correct length M4/M3 bolts.

tighten your belt, and double check the rods. your bearing should only be doing "guiding", but any tension force from your belt.

By adding this mod, your belt tension is finally withstood by your X-rods. you can use 2 of this clamp, but 1 should be enough, make sure the other end (the other Y carriage) are tightened.

you would not need this mod if you know what I am talking about, and confident about your X gantry set up (both X rods tightened so no force is transferred to your Y bearings)

comments.text:
Good Idea.
I think it is underrated.
comments.author: Stanley_Mobo

comments.text: Let me know how it works for you guys, it is working for me as my y rods are cb as well, any bending force is very  pronounced.

title: Mini HOTAS 45
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Basically the same design as my Mini HOTAS 40 but this is for larger gimbals with 45mm between mounting holes.

Parts needed:
2pcs gimbals CC45mm
10pcs 7mm momentary push switches
3pcs 3-way flip switches
6pcs 10x2mm rare earth magnets
6pcs M3 screws
6pcs M3 knurl nuts
1pcs USB-cable (A-connector and open ended), length depending on your need. For use with laptop I have only 60cm.
1pcs Rubber grommet suitable for USB cable
1pcs zip tie
1pcs BU0836A 12-Bit Joystick Controller: http://www.leobodnar.com/shop/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=94&products_id=219
1pcs BU0836A Break out Matrix board: http://www.leobodnar.com/shop/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=94&products_id=274

Note: I've also designed a smaller version for CC40mm gimbals: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2564784

Step 1. Print the box.

Step 2. Mount the knurl nuts in place using a solder iron. Make it hot and let it melt into the correct position.

Step 3 (optional). If you want to make the box nice spend some time to sand and plaster it smooth before applying paint.

Step 4. Glue magnets to box and supports. I use CA-glue with accelerator

Step 5. Insert a USB cable through the center hole of the box and solder to the BU0836. I use a rubber grommet to reduce dirt coming into the box.

Step 6. Solder USB cable to BU0836.

Step 7. Solder the BU0836 cards.

Step 8. Attach controls; joystick gimbal, switches and pots to the lid.

Step 9. Solder cables to the controls, twist them to reduce interference and make sure they are longer then you need.

Step 10. Trim cables with some extra cm to spare if the BU0836 is on the center bottom of the box.

Step 11. Solder controls to the BU0836 cards.

Step 12. Position BU0826 card in the bottom center of the box and pull on the USB cable so you have a few cm spare cm inside the box and attach the zip tie between the BU0826 and rubber grommet where it'll work as a strain relief.

Step 13. Hot glue the BU0836 cards (two dabs on either side so it is easy to detach if necessary).

Step 14. Use M3 screws and attach lid to box.

Step 15. Setup as a standrad joystick inthe simulator of your choice! :)

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Simple wall mounted slotted belt holder for your closet. These work well with regular belts, but also slide belts and belts that don't have an opening on the buckle that cannot be "hooked" as required with most belt racks/hangers out there.

Ver1 - a smaller footprint, L150mm x W28mm x H55.5mm. Holds up to 4 belts with a strap width up to 8mm, slots are 40mm long. You'll want to print this at 50-75% infill probably to make sure it has strength to take a bit of abuse.

Ver2 - a larger footprint, L182mm x W55mm x H62.1mm. Holds up to 5 belts with a strap width of up to 9mm, slots are 45mm long, slot top cutout is also +5mm larger (for maybe a bit deeper buckle). The entire top is also angled 5° to help prevent the belts from slipping off as easily if they get bumped. Additionally, between each belt slot on the bottom is a brace to give the whole thing more rigidity, the bottom/top plates are a bit thicker, screw holes larger and more reinforced, and it has an additional screw hole in the middle bottom. As a result of this strengthening you can get by with a much lower infill setting, 20-40%.

Both will turn out very solid and should stand up to bumping into it, pulling down on it, etc. Ver2 is probably a bit overkill. Ver2 will take just a bit longer to print, most of it offset by the much lower infill needed. TIP: If you have a smaller printbed base try rotating the object 45° on your slicer.

Extruder part for mounting the hotend and the two fan shrouds I remixed. Made the remix with tinkercad.

There are a lot of instructions for making a spring clothespin into a toy "gun" for shooting matchsticks or toothpicks. They work OK, but need some fiddling to get them cocked after shooting--the spring and matchstick often wedge, or the spring refuses to go into its latching slot. Printing your own allows making some improvements, like adding a plunger with a stop and a shaped end that transfers the spring into the cocked position. And, it has sights...

I use ABS in a FlashForge Creator. I print the plunger using solid fill, standing on its flat end, no raft.
I print the barrel standing on its output end, no raft. Either solid or 5% fill seem to work, but I'd think solid would be more durable.
I print the grip using a raft and support, barrel side upward. Leave the raft in place until you've finished gluing. I trim the plunger edges to make sure it's smooth, using a scraper or a wide-blade snap-off knife.
I scrape the slot in the barrel where the plunger has to slide, to make sure it's smooth. Insert the plunger into the slot, with the flat end toward the front (exit end) of the barrel. Make sure it slides freely. Insert the spring. A plier may be helpful. Insert one leg into the front crossways hole, then distort the spring and insert the other leg behind the plunger, so the plunger is trapped toward the front of the barrel. That keeps it out of your glue... Press the barrel into place without the glue once for practice. Put superglue (I use Gorilla) around the recessed edges on the upward-facing grip, including on the semicircular protruding post's curved surface. Press the barrel into the glue and let the glue set for an hour or so. (You can use acetone instead of superglue, but I find it harder to control.) When it's strong, you can cock the gun by ramming a stick down the barrel. The spring should slide off the plunger into the cocked-position slot. This seems to work better the second or third time. Insert your ammo (I've even shot bamboo skewers--it's pretty powerful). Matches with the heads removed, or single-ended toothpicks, work well too. This, like its clothespin cousin, is powerful enough to be very dangerous to eyes, so be careful where you point it when it's loaded. And now, you know how the first thing everyone says when you tell them you've got a 3D printer is "Are you going to print a gun?!!", now you can say "yes, want to see it?"

title: Adjustable Idler based on F625ZZ bearings

description.text:
An adjustable idler to be mounted using a 20x40x1,5mm edge profile on a 2020-beam.
The idler has a holder holding the 2 flanged F625FF bearings, a guide to lock the direction of the idler and a knob containing a wingnut to adjust the tension on the belt.

Printing
I printed this one in PETG using a 0,6mm nozzle and 0,2mm layers (could be thicker).
Support is needed for the knob.

Mounting
First insert a hex head M4x20mm screw in the bottom of the holder.. This should be a very tight fit in the cavity for the nut. Heating (and a bit of force) may help.
the bearings are mounted on a M5x30mm bolt&nut.Put a spacer between bearing and holder on both sides. Bearings are mounted with flanges to the outside (of course).
The guide is placed as shown in the pictures.
Insert the wingnut in the knob and fix the idler combination on the aluminum profile.

BTW . I used a bit of superglue to fix the guide to the alu. Orientation is set by the small notch.

added the drawing for the alu mounting profile (scale 1/1)

title: zwZ5Case – Sony Xperia Z5 Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
At Thingiverse there is a few cases for Sony Xperia Z5, but non of them meets my expectations. This is why I have designed a new and better one.

This phone case fits perfectly on phone and don't make phone much bigger. Top and bottom of phone is opened to allow access them by bigger connectors and docking station. All edges that can be touched by finger are rounded.

I have printed it in to colors for better effect. I also have published two different versions of case:

  • first one have all logos from phone copied to case, this require printer with great resolution to print all details,
  • second one have only side logo so whole back side is blank.

When printing please look closely at my printer settings to get same result as me. Your printer need to be good calibrated.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

This print is optimised for layer height 0.2mm (in this way you can be sure that inner size exactly meet phone dimensions) and 0.4mm nozzle (all walls are exactly 1.2mm thick). Please remember that layer height is very important. If set to other value phone probably can't fit. Don't need to set dimensional adjustments.

Supports are not required if your printer supports bridging for buttons.

title: SD Card Reader Frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Used in conjunction with this SD card reader:

http://www.ebay.com/itm/TF-Micro-SD-To-TF-Card-Extension-Cable-Adapter-Flexible-Extender-For-Car-GPS-YG-/401390128732?hash=item5d74b74e5c:g:AOoAAOSwGdhZnktp

Similar designs of SD card reader will work too.

Installation is simple, remove the plastic casing around the internals of the SD card reader. It was a very simple process that only required prying with an Exacto knife to open the seam of said casing. The printed parts are made to be a perfect fit around the internal PCB and metal shielding. Simply drop in the SD card reader (the back plate has four tabs that secure the PCB side. The metal shielding faces the front plate with the SD card text.) and snap both sides of the printed casing around it. The rear of the casing has through-holes for M3 screws however i designed it to be a snug fit so mine snapped together without hardware. I mounted it to the right of my display for easy access.

Anet A6

Yes

Solid

Notes:

Lay back plate on its back. Front plate is laid down with text facing up. Support is needed for these files. Zig-Zag is best and easiest to remove.
